entry.title: SAP Best Practices for Solution Quotation Management (7HB)
entry.content:
With SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02, we have delivered an SAP Best Practices scenario for Solution Quotation Management.

7HB - Solution Quotation Management with SAP CPQ 

The SAP S/4HANA Quotation Management with SAP CPQ offers customers the capability to create quotations for sales and service contract products in SAP CPQ. After the customer accepts the proposal the SAP CPQ Quote creates Sales Order and Service Contract automatically. The linkage document in between is the SAP Solution Quote document, which holds information about SAP CPQ Quote ID and the document ID of Sales Order and Service Contract.

(fig 1. SAP CPQ Integration with Solution Order Management in SAP S/4HANA )

Let‚Äôs start by looking in some more detail at the SAP Configure, Price, Quote integration with Solution quotation Management in SAP S/4HANA , Private Edition. SAP CPQ enables salespeople to create complex product configurations with tailored pricing and customized attributes with ease. The seamless pre-defined integration of SAP CPQ and solution quotation  in SAP S/4HANA  is implemented via BTP Cloud Integration and encompasses the transfer of pricing and product configuration data via CPS, and master data replication via MDI. The new scope item titled Solution Quotation Management with SAP CPQ (7HB) has been created for which contains the standard mapping logic required for implementing the integration.

(fig 2 SAP CPQ Integration with Solution Order Management process flow diagram)


The integration enables salespeople to leverage the full set of CPQ capabilities to create customized quotes. In the SAP CPQ front end, the order is configured and calculated based on the selection of available attributes. Once the quote is confirmed by the customer and the order is placed, it is handed over to solution order management in SAP S/4HANA  for further processing.  When the Solution Order has been processed, the status in CPQ is also updated to show that the order has been placed for fulfilment. The integration initially supports configurable and non-configurable sales and service contract products, with further product types to be added in future releases. Via the standard OData API, the initial creation, as well as read, update and delete operations are supported.

The system requirements for a successful configuration:

  1. SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition
  2. SAP CPQ
  3. SAP Business Technology Platform
  4. SAP Cloud Integration
  5. SAP Variant Configuration and Pricing
  6. SAP Master Data Integration
  7. SAP Event Mesh

entry.title: Introducing the RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench
entry.content:
Embarking on the RISE with SAP journey to transition to a private cloud environment can be overwhelming, but with the RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench, you have a powerful ally at your disposal to support you with the technical procedures and make them nearly seamless. Developed collaboratively with SAP Enterprise Cloud Services, the workbench is a dedicated tool ensuring a standardized and automated path to the private cloud, irrespective of your preferred migration approach.

What is the RISE with SAP system transition workbench?

The RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench is designed to be an extension of the family of software logistics tools such as SWPM and SUM in the context of private cloud transitions. It builds upon their capabilities to provide a highly automated guided procedure from the start to the end of the technical transition process.

 The RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench supports a growing portfolio of migration approaches, which can be used for all SAP NetWeaver-based on HANA target systems. Detailed documentation is available for each supported approach, providing clear guidelines and insights on how to proceed with your specific migration requirements. 

At the time of writing, the following approaches are available, either generally or as part of out early adopter program

    • SAP HANA Tenant Copy
    • SAP HANA Backup and Recovery
    • Homogeneous "Update and Copy"
    • System Conversion using SUM 2.0 (DMO with System Move)
    • System Conversion using SUM 2.0 (DMOVE2S4)

Each migration approach is facilitated through a structured guided procedure, referred to as "a cockpit". This cockpit is meticulously crafted to guide users through the technical procedure and is split into two main phases: the uptime phase and the downtime phase. This structure ensures that users have a clear understanding and control over the entire process.

 

New approaches and improvements are continuously bringing added, and you can track the same in our release note, and documentation.

What are the key benefits?

  • Extensive automated pre-requisite check report per migration approach, engineered to considerably reduce manual effort in verifying the system readiness for the selected approach and ensuring that all necessary criteria are met in a timely manner, reducing unplanned delays in the project runtime.
  • Automation integrated into the workbench. This automation is crafted to significantly minimize the time spent and the errors occurred in manual steps of the process, like system preparation, configuration, validation, etc. Reducing the amount of manual steps results in a stable, efficient, reliable and repeatable migration.
  • Reduced post-processing timelines by SAP ECS. The workbench ensures a consistent with SAP ECS‚Äôs standard and expectations, state of the system at the time of handover, which substantially decreases the need for time consuming follow-up actions and corrections.

Who is it for?

The RISE with SAP system transition workbench is available to all customers transitioning into the private cloud, supported by their respective migration teams, whether they are qualifying partners or SAP directly. Access to the workbench is straightforward, as it comes pre-installed on the migration server designated for the migration purpose. 

Staying Updated

Keeping the workbench up-to-date is easy. The latest version of the tool is maintained in the release note, and updates can be requested at any time through a service request in SAP for Me.

Your feedback matters

We value your input and are continuously working to improve the RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench. If you have any feedback or suggestions, please use the send feedback form in the tool or reach out to us directly.

Summary

The RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench is not just a tool - it's your navigation system in the digital transformation landscape. By radically reducing manual efforts, minimizing errors, and streamlining processes, it ensures that your journey to the private cloud is as smooth and efficient as possible. Check out our documentation and early adopter program and discover how you can leverage this incredible inovation to facilitate your migration endeavors.

entry.title: One of SAP TM's hidden gems: The Load Utilization Determination Component
entry.content:
I've found that in SAP Transportation Management, some very useful components don't always get the attention they deserve. This clearly applies to the Load Utilization Determination component, and this short blog post intends to rectify this somewhat.

What It Does

Simply put, this component answers an important question: "What transportation resources will I need for this set of products?" It does this by combining Package Building and Load Consolidation capabilities to run a simulation for a set of products and resources. The component doesn't actually create shipments or change your data - it just shows you what would be needed to move your products. The following result screenshot of test report /SCMTMS/TEST_PLN_LUD illustrates this, by listing the resources with utilization percentages for the packages (pallets) which were placed by the load consolidation components. The pallets themselves where created for the products using the unified package building component:

Practical Applications and Business Value

This tool helps in several business situations:

  • Resource Forecasting: Planning your transportation needs for upcoming sales periods based on expected orders, helping you secure the right carriers and vehicles ahead of time.

  • Bid Preparation/Sales order processing: When responding to customer requests, you can quickly estimate what transportation you'll need, allowing for more accurate cost estimates.

  • Scenario Planning: Test different approaches by seeing how changes in packaging or routing might affect your resource needs.

An example might look like this: A electronics distributor receives a rush order: 200 laptops, 150 monitors, and 300 accessories going to Walldorf. Before committing to same-day delivery, they run LUD:

  • Input: Product quantities + available truck types
  • Output: "You'll need 2 standard trucks at 85% capacity, or 1 large truck at 60% capacity"
  • Decision: Quote customer for large truck option with room for additional orders.

Getting Started

Setting up this component requires some basic configuration work with your planning profile (including load consolidation and unified package building settings) and master data. Note 3618303 provides basic information on how to consume this component in your custom project. The component is available for TM 9.6 and S/4HANA 1809 onwards.

Other options

Consulting solution

If a custom implementation is not an option for you, you could also take a look at the consulting solution for Transport Load Consolidation, which has implemented a process that consumes this component and integrates into sales order and delivery processes. Please refer to note 3045005 for further information on this solution.

Standard solution

As I mentioned above, we currently have no standard solution that embeds this functionality in a TM process. We do have plans in that direction, so if you have requirements or feedback around this we would love to hear from you.

entry.title: Now Available: Release Navigator for SAP Cloud ERP Private featuring 2023 FPS03
entry.content:
Stop Avoiding Releases & Embrace Cloud Innovation

We acknowledge that upgrading ERP technology presents a complex and time-intensive challenge. It is inherent that ensuring seamless integration of new innovations with existing technical APIs and third-party software requires diligent preparation. Unlike the swift upgrades associated with cellular devices, ERP Private technology necessitates a more intricate approach. Otherwise, organizations utilizing ERP Private solutions would readily adopt the latest innovations upon releases.

In response to these challenges, SAP Enterprise Support has introduced the release navigator for SAP Cloud ERP Private. This comprehensive digital library offers up-to-date release information and enablement content, strategically organized for ease of access. The release navigator provides valuable guidance on release timelines, introducing insights into new feature enablement, and supports the change management process. By staying informed on upcoming releases, organizations are better equipped to navigate the complexities of ERP Private software upgrades. Take a look today!

 

Fictional Use Case

Situation #1: Globex, a fictional multinational enterprise, operates across several industries such as manufacturing, supply chain, and procurement, leveraging distinct lines of business (LoBs). To manage its complex operations, Globex has decided to implement SAP Cloud ERP Private. As the enterprise anticipates an upcoming system upgrade, it is imperative for Globex to access detailed release information and enablement content associated with the new features. This proactive approach will mitigate potential system disruptions and ensure that the organization fully capitalizes on the benefits of the latest innovations across its operations.

 

Resolution #1: By leveraging the release navigator, Globex efficiently accesses the Release Calendar located on the Product Specific page (see Figure 1: Product Specific page) to track upcoming product releases. Additionally, Globex benefits from curated release content and enablement resources, specifically tailored for manufacturing, supply chain, and procurement lines, conveniently organized under the Lines of Business tab. This streamlined approach accelerates the process of locating and scaling the necessary resources to comprehend the features being adopted.

 Figure 1: Product Specific page

 

Situation #2: Globex needs to be able to point new employee's to the latest information on the tool and does not have time to walk them through how to use it.

Resolution #2: Globex can access integrated content and enablement features directly in the release navigator, providing valuable resources for their organization. Each main page features a blue light bulb icon that users can select to access additional information and a guided tour of that page. Furthermore, new users can be directed to the Get Assistance page located within the side menu (refer to Figure 2: Get Assistance page). This page includes a link to a curated blog tag within the SAP Community, offering access to a collection of blogs specifically related to the release navigator. Additionally, new users will have access to an authenticated version of the tool that supports over 40 languages for translation. The translation feature can be activated via the shell bar, located at the top right corner of each page.

Figure 2: Get Assistance page

 

Connect with Us

We value your input and encourage you to share any feedback for specific content requests for future updates to the release navigator. Please feel free to contribute your suggestions in the Comments section below this post. You can also leave your feedback directly in the release navigator by selecting the User Feedback inside the side menu (see Figure 3: User Feedback page).

 Figure 3: User Feedback page

 

Always Bring Your Best,

Andrew Ford

entry.title: Deploy built-in SAP LogServ detection rules in Microsoft Sentinel and extend to your needs - Part 3
entry.content:
Find your way to our central blog series entry here.

Dear community,

Following the product release blog by SAP regarding the integration of SAP LogServ and Microsoft Sentinel, I am going to share some details on the built-in detection rules and how you can build upon them.

The most discussed log in my customer conversations so far was SAP HANA database. So, let‚Äôs start with that.

 

Discover the available built-in detections from the Content Hub

Find the relevant section both from the Azure or the unified Defender portal under Rule templates in the Analytics section. They are available from version 3.0.2 of the SAP LogServ solution.

 

Typical database threat scenarios involve tampering with audit log settings, admin authorizations or privileged role assignments.

We have taken the existing battle-proven Microsoft Sentinel Solution for SAP rules for HANA DB and translated them to be compatible with the LogServ schema. The raw log source is Syslog in both cases. So, the only remaining step was ‚Äúunboxing‚Äù of the JSON wrapper.

To understand the individual columns of the LogServ output, see SAP‚Äôs HANA Audit Trail Layout for Trail Target documentation. For ease of use we have numbered the columns and applied the same names SAP mentions on their docs.

 

Activate the new rules

Navigate to the Analytics pane and select the rule you want, click ‚ÄúCreate Rule‚Äù from the button with the three dots and follow the configuration wizard. See the severity classification and pre-defined MITRE attack framework mapping. These mappings help streamline your SOC analysts‚Äô triage efforts.

 

 

Verify the rule execution schedule and consider automated responses where feasible. Creating ServiceNow tickets for instance is a popular action. See my dedicated blog series on SOAR for SAP for inspiration.

From the ‚ÄúReview + Create‚Äù section click save. Your rule is now live!

 

Build upon or extend the provided analytic rules

Since the Kusto Query is fully transparent to you (see above screenshot) it is easy to derive your own tailored scenarios from it.

For instance, take analytic rule ‚ÄúDeactivation of Audit Trail‚Äù and extend the client IP address attribute (client_ip_address__col_7) to project in plain English if that is an internal or external IP.

| extend GeoLocation= iff(ipv4_is_private(client_ip_address__col_7),
dynamic({"IsPrivate": true}),
geo_info_from_ip_address(client_ip_address__col_7))

I have a feeling this might be of interest during your incident triage process üòâ

 

Final Words

That‚Äôs a wrapüåØ. You saw today how to discover the built-in analytic rules of the SAP LogServ solution in Microsoft Sentinel and how easy it is to extend them for your own individual needs. The rule catalog gets extended continuously based on customer demand.

Your existing investments in SAP infrastructure detections in Sentinel can easily be made compatible with the LogServ schema, because SAP simply forwards the logs unaltered as raw messages. The only required step is the unboxing of their JSON root message.

#Kudos to @Hemanth_Kusampudi and team for the partnership.

Get started with your deployment from here today.

Which detections or analytic rules for RISE do you need most? Let me know in the comments or reach out directly.

Cheers Martin

entry.title: First smoke test after SAP LogServ solution deployment in Microsoft Sentinel - Part 0
entry.content:
Find your way to our central blog series entry here.

Dear community,

Due to the asynchronous integration between SAP LogServ and Microsoft Sentinel, it's advisable to perform a smoke test yourself before sharing your config data with SAP. This helps confirm if your receiving connector setup works and ensures the correct configuration will be shared with SAP the first time round.

 

Run a smoke test for ease of mind

Once the SAP LogServ push-connector is deployed on Microsoft Sentinel, you can start posting data towards its data collection endpoint. Use the provided REST client collection, or scripts to replicate the exact requests details that LogServ is performing too.

Maintain the variables as per your environment, see the LogServ sample payload and start posting. A working request shows http code 204 with no content on the response. See a sample output from the provided powershell script for reference. I prefer REST clients but people are different üòé

 

Find the parameters from the SAP LogServ Sentinel connector wizard on initial connect (see screenshot below). You can also get them directly from the individual resources. The data collection endpoint and data collection rule are created in the same resource group as your Log Analytics workspace underpinning Sentinel. They are prefixed with ‚ÄúSAPLogServ‚Äù. The app registration on Entra ID can be found from the Entra Application ID field.

 

Use the 2 KQL queries below to inspect your first data entry on the SAPLogServ_CL table in Sentinel.

SAPLogServ_CL
| take 10
SAPLogServ_CL
| summarize count() by clz_dir, clz_subdir
| order by clz_dir asc, clz_subdir asc

 

Wait a minute or two on first try. The population of new tables takes a short time initially.

 

Hurray you have a functioning data collection endpoint for the SAP LogServ dataüéâ

Now, continue your onboarding journey by sharing the config data with SAP over your chosen channel. Find the details on SAP's blog here.

What if you don‚Äôt see the data entry on the LogServ table?

  1. Verify the connection details: Did you really hit the right endpoint? Are you looking in the right tenant and log analytics workspace?
  2. Verify selection criteria: Is your Time range filter accurate? The smoke tests create entries for NOW or 30mins earlier in UTC.
  3. Did enough time pass on the initial table population? Consider a retry of the KQL query.
  4. Verify the Data collection rule has not been changed to filter all results or similar. See this blog part and KQL snippet for more details.

 

Deployment fully messed up?

The simplest way to a fresh start is a delete and redeployment of the Log Analytics workspace. In case that is not an option you need to delete the LogServ connector resources to reset the LogServ solution in Sentinel. The data collection endpoint, data collection rule and entra id app registration can be deleted from the Azure portal. But the data connector itself needs to be deleted via API.

For your convenience, use this REST API request collection to drop the resources. Once performed the LogServ connector UI will activate the deploy button again. In case you went fully bazooka and also deleted the SAPLogServ_CL table from your Log Analytics worksapce that needs to be reverted too. If the table had data you need to run a restore operation from Azure CLI.

 

Final Words

That‚Äôs a wrapüåØ. You saw today how to streamline your onboarding experience of SAP LogServ in Microsoft Sentinel. Simple smoke tests ensure a speedy onboarding and confidence in the shared setup configuration.

#Kudos to @Hemanth_Kusampudi and team for the partnership.

Get started with your deployment from here today.

Cheers Martin

entry.title: Against all odds ‚Äì Integrated Supplier on the SAP Business Network ...
entry.content:
Against all odds ‚Äì OQEMA AG managed to integrate the S/4HANA Cloud, private edition with the SAP Business Network (integration scenario scope item 4A1) and successfully went live with the pilot market

Introduction

OQEMA AG has been an integrated (system-to-system integration) supplier on the SAP Ariba Network (now called SBN) since 2019, leveraging the so-called Business Suite Add-on (BSAO).

It‚Äôs no coincidence, that in the same year, DSAG and SAP launched an initiative to jointly develop a successor solution for the BSAO. In September 2019, as part of this initiative, the DSAG submitted a list of BSAO deficiencies/shortcomings to SAP. This list was then compiled and prioritized by the member companies of the DSAG Ariba Working Group (beginning of April 2020) and identified several must-have requirements, out of which one has been the need for "Provide an approval workflow for order inbound changes." It may sound a minor requirement, but it's probably a key must-have for most customers, as a simple change to the order on the customer (buyer) side can lead to inconsistent changes to the sales order on the supplier side with corresponding business disruptions in the downstream process.

An example: The customer orders product A for delivery date X. The sales order is created and processed on the supplier side. Typically, an outbound delivery is created with a certain lead time. From this point on, the delivery date can no longer be changed (the delivery would have to be deleted). However, the customer (buyer) can submit an order change (update) at any time and, for example, adjust the desired delivery date. Due to an integration error, the supplier does not check whether the delivery date can still be changed at all. Instead, the date is "simply" changed. This problem already existed in the previous integration with SAP ECC. However, there was at least the option to detect and prevent this situation using a customer-specific extension (BAdI). The new solution does not offer a corresponding extension option. The idea behind "Provide an approval workflow for order inbound changes" would not only solve this problem but also improve the process, giving both parties visibility in case of changes to the purchase order.

At the end of February 2022, SAP approached us and asked us to create an influence request, which would be required for the implementation of the solution. This influence request, dated March 1, 2022, has now received 43 votes.

Subsequently, the initiative worked together on the design of the solution. In 2024, a user experience test was successfully conducted with several companies using a PoC.

And now? We're now in 2025, and SAP still hasn‚Äôt been able to confirm any release date for the solution. We can only speculate about the reasons for this, and yes, they may be diverse. However, one important aspect could be the "chicken and egg" problem. Since 2023, there has been a code split between the SAP S/4HANA public cloud and the on-premises/private cloud.

4A1, the scope item that succeeds BSAO, has been generally available (GA) since the S/4HANA 2020 release, but adoption appears to have been low, especially in the public cloud (although not limited to this environment) - not really surprising, isn‚Äôt it?

Without adoption, there's no priority and no development resources ‚Äì without improvements, there's no adoption. A dilemma!

Our challenge

We at OQEMA AG knew that we would need to replace our existing integration with SAP SBN and say goodbye ‚Äì both to our ECC and to the BSAO. But how can we achieve this if the ‚Äúproduct‚Äù has functional gaps and there is no real commitment to solve them?

Our way

We had some support from SAP (huge thanks to those who always supported us and believed in us) and many many creative workarounds on our end. In May 2025 we successfully went live with our pilot scenario. Currently, we have integrated the order-in and order-confirmation process for direct material with SAP S/4HANA, private cloud release 2023 FPS1.

What‚Äôs next?

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Creating a Fiori tile for ABAP reports
entry.content:
TL;DR ‚Äì How to create a tile on the SAP Fiori launchpad to run an ABAP report ‚Äì based on customer experiences. This is a gap-filling technique that is useful for moving existing custom ABAP reports in system conversion projects, or where an SAP predefined report is missing from the SAP Fiori apps reference library.   Alternatives are given at the end of the blog post..

You have an existing ABAP report that you want to run from the SAP Fiori launchpad.  How do you create a tile to run an ABAP report? In the example in this blog post you will see how you can create a tile using the predefined transaction SA38. This is a simple 3-step approach for a sandbox environment. For a development environment, you should consider creating a custom transaction. You will find a brief discussion at the end of this blog post in section Alternative approaches to consider.

 

Creating a tile from scratch is a 3-step process:

  1. Define the tile to launch the ABAP report.
  2. Reference the tile definition into your custom business role for the user.
  3. Adjust the role‚Äôs menu and authorizations for any authorizations needed to run the ABAP report.

Once you test your tile you can consider optional Next Steps.

Why create a tile for an ABAP report?

When transitioning from SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition, you're shifting from using SAP GUI to the SAP Fiori launchpad. This change lets you take advantage of new features offered by RISE with SAP S/4HANA via SAP Fiori apps. You've identified these new functionalities using tools like SAP Signavio. Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA - Finding business process improvements with SAP Signavio

Due to time and budget constraints, it's often not feasible to convert all existing user interfaces into SAP Fiori apps. You want to avoid creating a mixed experience for users; instead, you want them to access all applications‚Äîboth new and old‚Äîfrom a single platform.

The SAP Fiori launchpad enables you to integrate classic UIs, including GUI Transactions, Web Dynpro ABAP applications, WebClient UIs, and ABAP Reports. Many SAP GUI transactions and ABAP Reports are already available in the SAP Fiori apps reference library by filtering on All Apps for SAP S/4HANA.

However, custom ABAP "Z" reports and some SAP predefined ABAP reports, like batch-scheduled ones, may not be listed. For these situations, you might need to manually create a tile in the SAP Fiori launchpad.

Hints:

  • Refer to SAP Help - SAP Fiori launchpad - Administration Guide for how to create a tile for any GUI transaction. 
  • If you are not familiar with the terms technical catalog, business catalog, business role, or Launchpad App Descriptor Item (LADI), you can find these explained in the SAP Help ‚Äì SAP Fiori launchpad ‚Äì Administration Guide ‚Äì Setting up Launchpad Content ‚Äì About Launchpad Content
  • All screenshots shown on SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 system.  This same process can be used on SAP S/4HANA 2020 or higher.

P.s. If you are wondering why not just use the SAP Menu or User Menu feature in the App Finder, refer to my previous blog post 

SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì How to include GUI transactions in the launchpad ‚Äì User Menu versus Catalogs

 

Example Use Case

For customers using Project and Portfolio Management, it can be helpful to extend project roles such as Project Financial Controller (technical id SAP_BR_PROJ_FIN_CONTROLLER) with some additional ABAP reports that are not yet included in the SAP Fiori apps reference library.  

For example, report /RPM/FICO_INT_PLANNING_V2 is an ABAP report that can be scheduled, or optionally run manually. To run the report manually you want a tile on the SAP Fiori launchpad. You use this report to control when and how data from SAP Financials and Controlling (FI-CO) is a applied to projects managed by Portfolio and Project Management. 

Pro-tip: To verify your ABAP Report will run successfully on the SAP Fiori launchpad there are a couple of pre-checks you can do. 

  1. Run the ABAP Report in WebGUI. For example, using the direct WebGUI URL for your system's host and port such as:  http://<host>:<port>/sap/bc/gui/sap/its/webgui?~transaction=SA38
  2. If there any issues with any of the features of your report, check the WebGUI restrictions and limitations for your release to make sure you are NOT using a feature that will not work in a web browser. For SAP S/4HANA 2023 this is SAP Note 3417085 - 7.93: SAP GUI for HTML functionality / Limitations / Sp. Behaviour
  3. Worst case: If the ABAP Report is not web-browser ready - and this is rare - then review section Alternative approaches to consider.

 

Prerequisites

Assumptions:

  • Your SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA is already configured and active. If this has not been done, refer to Learning Video - Activating SAP Fiori Launchpad Using SAP Fiori Foundation Task List

You will need to know:

  • The ABAP report id.  This could be a SAP predefined ABAP report or a custom ABAP report.
  • The technical catalog that will hold the tile definition.
  • The business catalog that will hold the reference to the tile definition.
  • Which business role contains the business catalog.
  • A test user id assigned to the business role that will contain the tile.
  • 1 cross-client workbench transport request
  • 1 client-specific customizing transport request
  • Package Id for your launchpad content.

Pro-tip: It's helpful to keep all SAP Fiori launchpad content in the same package.

For the example use case:

  • Custom technical catalog Z_TC_PROJ_FIN_EXTRA has been created to hold custom apps for Project Financials.
  • Custom business catalog Z_BC_PROJ_FIN_PORTFOLIO has been created to collect custom apps for Project Finance ‚Äì Portfolio Management
  • The business catalog Z_BC_PROJ_FIN_PORTFOLIO has already been assigned to custom business role Z_BR_PROJ_FIN_CONTROLLER.

You will need access to Fiori launchpad content administration tools including:

  • Launchpad App Manager
  • Launchpad Content Manager Client-Specific
  • Role Maintenance (transaction PFCG)
  • Report execution transaction SA38

Hint: For this example, the Fiori Administration role (id Z_FIORI_FOUNDATION_ADMIN) has been used. This business role is generated by task list SAP_FIORI_FOUNDATION_S4. Refer to Learning Video - Activating SAP Fiori Launchpad Using SAP Fiori Foundation Task List generated by task list SAP_FIORI_FOUNDATION_S4. Authorizations to execute transactions PFCG and PFCGUPDATEROLEMENU were added to the admin role. In practice, the role maintenance tasks would be run by a security administrator user.

Step 1 ‚Äì Define the tile for the ABAP Report

First you need to define the tile for the SAP Fiori launchpad.

  • You define the tile by creating Launchpad App Descriptor Item (LADI). A LADI contains the tile definition that defines how the tile should appear, and the target mapping that defines which app is launched when the tile is selected in the launchpad.  
  • You define the tile once, and then later you reference the tile to one or more business roles. You typically define the tile in your Sandbox or Development system, then transport the changes to subsequent systems in your landscape as needed.
  • LADIs are created within cross-client technical catalogs. Because technical catalogs are cross-client, you will use a Workbench Transport Request to capture your changes ready for transport. Refer to SAP Help ‚Äì SAP Fiori launchpad ‚Äì Administration Guide ‚Äì Setting up launchpad content - Setting Up Technical Catalogs with the SAP Fiori Launchpad App Manager

Login as your Fiori launchpad content administrator.

Open the Launchpad App Manager.

On the tab Technical Catalogs, find and open the technical catalog that will contain the LADI definition.

Hint: You can optionally create a new standard catalog using the button New Standard Catalog on the same tab.

Select the option Add App > Transaction to add a new LADI for a transaction.

You will be asked to confirm the Package and Workbench Transport Request to capture your changes to the technical catalog.

For the field Transaction Code, enter SAP GUI transaction SA38.

Pro-tip: You should use transaction SA38 for business users executing reports. To avoid unnecessary authorizations being generated, do NOT use transaction SE38 which should only be used by developers who create reports.

Press the <ENTER> key. This will default in some information from SE93 such as:

  • Device Type settings
  • Application Component id
  • Default tile name

Adjust the following settings in tab Target Application Fields:

  • Semantic Object ‚Äì use the closest SAP Semantic object that fits with the main business object of the report.  For the example, because the report is run for project portfolios, the standard semantic object ProjectPortfolio is selected.
  • Action ‚Äì The action for the Semantic Object is freely definable. Enter a camel case verb that fits with purpose of the report. Action is set to integrateFICO4Planning
  • Target Application Title ‚Äì this is the link text that is shown whenever the app is displayed as a link, e.g. in Search Results, Related Apps, and List of Links dialogs. For the example use case, Target Application Title is set to Portfolio - Financial Periodic Planning and Integration.
  • Application Component ID ‚Äì this is the support component shown in the About and App Support dialogs to indicate where to search on SAP for Me for information. For the example, Application Component ID is set to PPM-PFM.

Pro-tip: There are more than 3K Semantic Objects delivered by SAP, with predefined dynamic navigation links to related launchpad contact, including any additional custom tiles you create. Avoid creating custom Semantic Objects as these are not linked to any existing apps, making it harder for users to navigate between apps.

Add the following parameters in tab Parameters:

  • Program ‚Äì set Default Value to your program id, and set Rename To value  RS38M-PROGRAMM
  • DynproNoFirstScreen  - set Default Value = 1
  • DYNP-OKCODE  - set Default Value = STRT to start the report

To complete the definition, you adjust the tile appearance in the tab Tiles.

Adjust the following settings in tab Tiles:

  • Tile texts - Title, Subtitle, and Information
  • Tile Keywords ‚Äì these are used to help find the tile when using Search on Apps
  • Tile icon ‚Äì you can use the value help to search for suitable icons

Select Save to save your LADI.

Step 2 ‚Äì Assign the tile definition to the business role

Launchpad content items ‚Äì such as apps - are directly assigned to business catalogs, and indirectly assigned to business roles. Business catalogs typically contain a small subset of closely related apps that are assigned together to one (or more) business roles.  Business catalogs and business roles are client-specific.  

Open the Launchpad Content Manager ‚Äì Client-Specific.

On the tab Catalogs, find and open the business catalog that will reference the LADI.

  • You can use an existing business catalog, or you can select Create to create a new business catalog.
  • If you create a new business catalog you will need to assign the business catalog to the business role. 

Find and add the LADI to the business catalog using the option Add Tiles/Target Mappings > Add Tile/TMs to selected catalog.

Find your LADI add reference it to your business catalog by selecting Add Tile/TM Reference.

Confirm the LADI has been added to your business catalog.

To check which roles use this business catalog, select Show Usage in Roles.

 

Step 3 ‚Äì Adjust the business role content and authorizations

You now need to adjust the related business role's content and authorizations.  The easiest way to do this is to use transaction PFCGUPDATEROLEMENU. This transaction runs program PRGN_COMPARE_ROLE_MENU.  You can also adjust the role manually in Role Maintenance transaction PFCG.

Run transaction PFCGUPDATEROLEMENU for the related business role(s).

Any mismatches with the current role content are highlighted by the traffic light in the first column.

Select the mismatched row(s). Adjust the role menu by selecting Adapt Menu.

Press Refresh to review the corrected role content.  Correcting the role content impacts the role's authorization status, which needs to be adjusted for the change in content.

Select Change Role to review and adjust the changes in the role's authorizations. 

Find the new entries for Authorization Object S_PROGRAM in class BC_C. These grant authorization to run the program. 

Adjust the authorization program setting the program id. Set authorization field P_PROGRAM to the program you want the user to run.

Adjust the activities so that the user can run the report. Set authorization field P_ACTION to SUBMIT.  Pro-tip: You can also set VARIANT if you want the user to save variants to minimize data entry. 

Generate the role to update the profile.

Confirm the authorizations profile status is now generated.

Pro-tip: If you want to use the changes immediately you may need to run a User Comparison in the Role Maintenance transaction PFCG. This updates the cache that holds the user's current authorizations. 

Review the User tab.  Make sure your test user is assigned to the role. Run the User Comparison for your test user.

Test your tile

You can now use your test user to test your tile from SAP Fiori launchpad using the App Finder.

Select the tile using your business catalog title or any part of the keywords or tile texts.

Select the tile to launch the report.

Next steps ‚Äì consider where to place your tile

Once you are satisfied the tile is working, you can decide where to place it to help the user find it during their day-to-day work.  For example, you can add the tile to any Page assigned to any of the role‚Äôs spaces.

You can find which space is assigned to your business role using either:

  • Launchpad Content Manager ‚Äì Client Specific - tab Roles - option Show Spaces
  • Overview of Role, Spaces and Pages (transaction /UI2/RSP_LIST)

Refer to SAP Help ‚Äì SAP Fiori launchpad ‚Äì Administration Guide ‚Äì Analyzing Spaces and Pages

Worth knowing: You maintain spaces in app F4834 Manage Launchpad Spaces. You maintain the related pages in app F4512 Manage Launchpad Pages.  Refer to Learning Video - Creating SAP Fiori Launchpad Layouts for Custom Business Roles.

 

Alternative approaches to consider

For improved usage tracking and role maintenance

Instead of using transaction SA38, you can define a custom transaction for your ABAP report id.  Using a custom transaction enables you to track the usage of this app by transaction code.  It can also be useful for the security administrator.  For example, from Role Maintenance (transaction PFCG) they can search for the custom transaction across all security roles.

You can define custom transactions in transaction SE93.  For example, you could define a report transaction or a parameter transaction.

  • Instead of entering the parameters in the LADI, you enter the parameters in the custom transaction.
  • Mark your transaction as suitable for SAP GUI for HTML so that others know you have already checked all its features work from the SAP Fiori launchpad. 
  • You then use your custom transaction to create your LADI and complete the changes to the business catalog and business role as explained above.

Refer to: SAP Help - ABAP Platform - ABAP Workbench Tools - Maintaining Transactions

For improved report design and behaviour

Consider updating your ABAP reports to newer versions that are optimized for cloud use and mobile devices. If a report is hard to use, lacks information, or could be improved with visuals, consider redesigning it for a better experience.

For example:

You might consider replacing it with a SAP Fiori elements app,  for example, using the floorplans List Report or Analytical List Page. Refer to SAP Design Guidelines.

  • Pro-tip: Make sure your developers are up-to-date with the latest recommended programming models such as Fiori Elements Flexible Programming Model Explorer and ABAP RESTful Programming Model.

Or you might consider replacing it with a SAP Analytics Cloud story, if you want to combine information from SAP S/4HANA and another solution. Refer to Learning Journey - Designing Stories in SAP Analytics Cloud.

Becoming a SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA guru

You‚Äôll find much more on our  SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA topic page

entry.title: Selecting Business Processes for improvement during SAP S/4HANA upgrade project (Brownfield/SDT)
entry.content:
Problem statement:

Business process improvement topics are often curtailed (if not ignored) during system conversion (brownfield) and selective data transition (SDT) projects, as IT departments frequently lead these. Since 2015, SAP has delivered 3,800+ roadmap items in SAP S/4HANA; these features have improved business processes. If business process improvement is not considered, upgrading to SAP S/4HANA won‚Äôt enhance users' efficiency and effectiveness; it‚Äôs a lost opportunity. It‚Äôs vital that companies treat SAP S/4HANA as a transformation project and not a technology upgrade.

Background:

Many large enterprises are undergoing transformation projects by converting their legacy SAP ERP (ECC) to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (SAP S/4HANA). Usually, business users are excited to utilize new capabilities during the discovery phase. Business process improvements and the implementation of best practices are often discussed with enthusiasm.

Fast-forward a few months, and the System Integrators (SIs) are selected. Then, detailed scoping, a project plan, and a contract are finalized. Too often, the project mantra becomes ‚Äòupgrade now and improve business processes later.‚Äô

Often, the business team sits on the fringes and has limited influence in the key transformation activities. The project performs upgrades, and the business users see the new S/4 as the same old ECC in a slightly different UI; they don‚Äôt see any meaningful improvement in their way of working.

The real questions are?

  1. What strategy can management deploy in the definition phase so that the business processes that drive an organization are in focus when the project kicks off? 
  2. What steps can the project team take to ensure that focused business process improvements have a reasonable chance of being implemented once the system is upgraded?

Develop Business Strategy Map and Business Architecture

Business and IT teams understand the benefits that business process improvement can provide. Business benefits are often front and center in a project proposal with a value case to justify the project. However, as described above, improvement objectives are diluted as the project progresses through various stages from definition to implementation. Business process improvement topics must be inserted in every project stage to avoid this dilution. You can create a business strategy map and architecture to do so. The following section includes steps to develop a business strategy map in each SAP Activate Phase.

Step 1: Define the North Star in the Discover Phase

Early in the transformation program, agree on the project's strategic objectives and define them as your ‚ÄòNorth Star‚Äô. North Star objectives help to define a business case and provide direction throughout the project lifecycle. Utilize these to build a strong corporate sponsorship and governance that includes IT and Business leaders.

Figure 1 - Business Strategy Map - Strategic Priorities

Often, these are too abstract and high-level.  You will get buy-in at the executive level, but they are not granular/tangible enough to define the scope. These are hard to measure and especially difficult to link to tangible business processes.

Step 2: Erect lighthouses in the Prepare phase

The North Star is 440 light years away, and project teams are often navigating under cloudy skies (so to speak). You will need to develop lighthouses that will guide your project at a more operational level. Develop a detailed value case for each business unit and focus on a subset of capabilities for improvements, then ensure that these capabilities can be implemented independently by a single department. You can tackle cross-department capabilities once the platform is stabilized.

You must develop goals that various business units want to achieve in a given timeline. Developing goals is neither a complete requirements collection exercise nor an open invitation to include re-engineering process scope in the project. It‚Äôs an exercise to select a limited set of impactful objectives that the business wants to achieve and have synergy with the S/4 upgrade project. For example:

  • Improve user experience
  • Utilize inbuilt analytics
  • Utilize focused application features to make the process better (e.g. Universal journal, Live MRP, etc.)
  • Reduce customization where standard capabilities are available,
  • Items not in the scope of legacy ECC but that make sense should be included in the overall ERP.

These KPIs need to be achievable and agreed upon by all three concerned groups:

  1. Business managers (who are responsible for business process improvement)
  2. IT Managers (who often lead/sponsor this project)
  3. Project management team  (who executes this project and is responsible for its successful completion)

Include these objectives in RFPs/Contracts so the System integrators/Partners know what is expected. The project team should be accountable for achieving these KPIs.

Figure 2 - Business Strategy Map - Goals and Objectives with KPIs

Step 3: Draw maps and install guardrails in the Explore phase

Although a lighthouse provides direction, you must provide a map and compass for foggy and rainy days so individual business, functional and technical analysts can stay on the path. You must also set up guardrails with a governance structure to ensure processes are configured to achieve the defined objectives.

Utilize Business Architecture artifacts, such as Business Capability Model/Business Process Models [blog], to provide enough granularity to the responsible teams. As the image below shows, you can utilize ‚Äòbusiness capabilities‚Äô to link the business objectives and processes. You will also be able to link Solution Capabilities that should be used to enhance these business processes (remember the 3,800+ features of SAP S/4HANA).

You can also utilize visual indicators to indicate:

  1. Degree of change: A process change will occur when implementing a new solution. The ‚Äògreen‚Äô gradient in the following image shows how much change is expected in a given capability and process.
  2. Capability Maturity improvements: With the capability of new solutions and updated processes, the capability maturity level is expected to change. The number of dots on the left side of the box represents the ‚Äòcurrent‚Äô maturity level, and the number of dots on the right side represents the ‚Äòtarget‚Äô maturity level.

Figure 3 - Business Strategy Map - Business Capabilities, Solution Capabilities for initiative

Define a ‚Äòto-be‚Äô business process list for improvement, focusing on these outcomes. 

  1. Resist the temptation to pick the most complex/most-integrated processes. Ideal processes are often restricted within one business domain, reducing dependency and risk of managing integration while the platform is upgrading. 
  2. Develop detailed business process flowcharts that include the steps (sequence), application, roles, data, and reports required to achieve desired outcomes. Utilize these processes to perform a fit-to-standard workshop and understand delta requirements. 
  3. If you selectively transfer data from ECC to S/4, use this opportunity to simplify and streamline the Enterprise Structure across organizational units. For example, rationalize company codes/plants, align cost center hierarchy with organization hierarchy, etc. Fine-tuning the enterprise structure sets the stage for process simplification.

Figure 4 - In-scope business processes for the project

 Tools 1) SAP LeanIX to develop and manage a business strategy map, 2) SAP Signavio to manage business processes.

Step 4: Deploy guides and guards in the Realize phase

Once the scope is finalized, you will need dedicated guides who are empowered and responsible to make decisions in the field to ensure that the objectives are achieved. Assign business process owners who act as guides during process realization phase. They will utilize BCM/Business processes to validate work as it is being developed.

There will be debates about 'one more feature' vs. 'timely completion of the project'. Set up a Process Governance and Solution Standardization Board (or equivalent). This governance structure allows your team to have a forum to discuss options to achieve targeted improvements.

There will be trade-offs between adopting a standard and customizing (implementing complex logic) for business advantage, legal, or compliance reasons. You will need guardrails, such as process governance, and a solution standardization board that provides a forum to discuss these trade-offs.

Step 5: Look up once in a while in the Deploy/Go-live Phase

Once in a while, look up. Hopefully, you will see a North Star and admire your progress and how far you have come from ‚Äòas-is‚Äô to ‚Äòto-be‚Äô processes. You have completed all the work and are doing final testing. Your ‚Äòto-be‚Äô processes are ready for the world (i.e. your enterprise). As you may expect, there will be resistance with a phrase like ‚Äòthis is not how we have done things in the past‚Äô. If handled correctly, new processes will stick, and in a few months, you will be able to measure the KPIs you set earlier in step 3.

Step 6: Live long and prosper in the Run phase

Transformation is not a destination; it‚Äôs a journey. If you successfully transform select processes, pick another setup process and start the cycle again. This time, your task will be easier as the ‚Äònew‚Äô platform is already running, and you have experience executing process transformation.

Conclusion:

Successful transformation relies on streamlined processes, the latest application (technology) and accurate data. Treating the upgrade as a mere technical task without considering these elements will not yield the desired business outcomes. Invest your time and energy in developing a business strategy map early in the project, and include this as part of the regular governance model. Remember that the upgrade to SAP S/4HANA is only a task to be completed, not a business outcome.

Every transformation initiative requires intensive work at the company's grassroots level, ‚ÄòYour business process‚Äô.

It seems you believe in meaningful transformation; otherwise, you wouldn‚Äôt have read this article. Please share your experience, advice, or comments.
